displaytitle: Chocolate cup depicting a mythic scene
creditline: Gift of Stephanie H. Bernheim and Leonard H. Bernheim Jr. in honor of Gillett G. Griffin
catalograisonne:
K7727
MS2085
LC-cb2-364 (Maya Photographic Archive, Dumbarton Oaks)

titles.title: Chocolate cup depicting a mythic scene

texts.textentryhtml: The brilliant palette of orange, yellow, and white, as well as the elaborate hieroglyphs, on this cup meant for drinking chocolate are thought to have been the signature painting style of the kingdom of El Zotz in north-central Peten, Guatemala, where archaeological excavations have been undertaken recently. The painted imagery offers a rare and fascinating alternative view into the narrative of the Maize God. Conveyed in three distinct scenes, the story follows the deity—identified by his distinctive tonsured hairdo—from his initial departure from the underworld, through his conception and mother's care, to his safe arrival at the earth's surface.

Karl Heinz Nottebohm, Guatemala City, Guatemala. [The Stendahl Gallery, Los Angeles, CA]. George Heyer, TX or NY. Alphonse Jax. Leonard and Stephanie Bernheim; gift to the Princeton University Art Museum in honor of Gillett G. Griffin, 2005.
